sections.founder: What Shorta changed in my workflow

aiGenerator.question: Is Shorta just another AI script generator?
aiGenerator.answer: No. Shorta focuses on analysis and feedback first. Generation is optional and guided by what actually needs fixing.

monthlyPlan.question: Why don't you offer a monthly plan?
monthlyPlan.answer: Building a successful YouTube Shorts channel is a long-term business, not a quick experiment. Annual pricing ensures you're committed to the process and gives you enough runway to see real results. We're building for creators who are serious about growth.

chatgpt.question: Can't I just use ChatGPT?
chatgpt.answer1: You can â€” but ChatGPT is trained on old data and gives you generic hooks.
chatgpt.answer2: Shorta analyzes recent viral Shorts, extracts what's working now, and matches the best hook to your specific content â€” not just random viral patterns.
chatgpt.answer3: It's like having a researcher who watches trending Shorts daily and tells you exactly which hook will work for your topic.

niche.question: What if my niche isn't productivity or AI?
niche.answer: Shorta analyzes structure and viewer behavior patterns, not niche-specific buzzwords.

creativity.question: Will this replace my creativity?
creativity.answer: No. It removes uncertainty so you can focus on creative decisions that matter.

generateTime.question: How long does it take to generate scripts?
generateTime.answer: Less than 5 minutes. Paste your references, enter your topic, and get high quality storyboard instantly.

otherPlatforms.question: Can I use this for TikTok or Instagram Reels?
otherPlatforms.answer: You can â€” the principles of viral short-form content apply across platforms. However, our current focus is on YouTube Shorts, so the analysis and patterns are optimized for that platform.

dataStorage.question: Do you store my channel data?
dataStorage.answer: We store summarized channel data (not raw videos) so the AI can generate the best content specifically for your audience and style. Your data is never shared with third parties.

scores.calculationExplanation: The Overall Score (0-100) is calculated from 4 weighted categories:
scores.hookWeight: Hook ({percent}%) - How quickly you grab attention
scores.deterministic: Deterministic: Same video always gets the same score.

guidance.talking_head: For talking head videos, your hook energy and speaking delivery matter most. Eye contact, pace, and a clear promise in the first 2 seconds are key.
guidance.gameplay: For gameplay clips, the opening action and highlight moment are critical. Fast pacing and a clear climax keep viewers watching.
guidance.demo: For demo videos, show the end result first â€” then walk through the how. Cut dead time (loading, typing), zoom into key UI areas, and add text overlays for context.
guidance.other: Hook strength and story structure are the biggest factors. Make sure you deliver on the promise from your opening.

nextStep.title: Next Step
nextStep.description: Apply fixes below, then generate an improved storyboard â†’
nextStep.step1: Click "Apply Fix" on issues you want to address
nextStep.step2: Your fixes collect in the sidebar â†’
nextStep.step3: Hit "Generate" to create a director's storyboard with your fixes applied

changes.title: Approved Changes
changes.noChangesSub: Review suggestions in the Analysis panel and approve actions to add them here.

tooltips.timeToClaim: Seconds until first promise/claim. Target: under 1.5s.
tooltips.patternBreak: Energy/visual variation in first 1-3 seconds. Higher is better.
tooltips.specifics: Numbers, timeframes, names in hook. More = more compelling.
tooltips.hookQuestion: Opens with a question or contradiction to hook viewers.

tooltips.beatCount: Number of content sections. Ideal: 3-6 for Shorts.
tooltips.hasPayoff: Does the video deliver on its hook promise?
tooltips.loopCue: Does ending reference the start or encourage rewatch?

tooltips.speakingPace: Words per second. Ideal: 3-4 WPS for comprehension.
tooltips.complexity: Sentence complexity. Lower is easier to follow.
tooltips.topicJumps: Sudden context switches. Fewer = easier to follow.
tooltips.redundancy: Repetition without new info. Lower is more concise.

tooltips.volumeConsistency: Loudness stability. Higher = more consistent audio levels.
tooltips.audioQuality: Noise level and clarity. Higher = cleaner audio.
tooltips.fillerWords: Count of "um", "uh", "like", etc. Lower = cleaner delivery.
tooltips.energyVariation: Vocal energy changes to maintain interest. Monotone = less engaging.

shotTypes.ECU: Extreme Close-Up: Very tight shot on a specific detail (eyes, hands, object)
shotTypes.CU: Close-Up: Tight shot of a face or object, showing emotion or detail
shotTypes.MCU: Medium Close-Up: Head and shoulders framing, common for dialogue
shotTypes.MS: Medium Shot: Waist-up framing, balances subject and environment
shotTypes.MWS: Medium Wide Shot: Knee-up framing, shows body language
shotTypes.MLS: Medium Long Shot: Shows most of the body with some environment
shotTypes.WS: Wide Shot: Full body with some environment visible
shotTypes.EWS: Extreme Wide Shot: Establishes location, subject appears small
shotTypes.POV: Point of View: Camera shows what a character sees
shotTypes.OTS: Over the Shoulder: Shot from behind one person looking at another
shotTypes.2-shot: Two Shot: Frame includes two people
shotTypes.INSERT: Insert Shot: Close-up of an object or detail relevant to the scene
shotTypes.insert: Insert Shot: Close-up of an object or detail relevant to the scene

cameraMovements.static: Static: Camera stays fixed in position
cameraMovements.pan: Pan: Camera rotates horizontally left or right
cameraMovements.tilt: Tilt: Camera rotates vertically up or down
cameraMovements.dolly: Dolly: Camera physically moves toward or away from subject
cameraMovements.truck: Truck: Camera physically moves left or right
cameraMovements.track: Tracking Shot: Camera follows a moving subject
cameraMovements.zoom: Zoom: Lens adjusts to make subject appear closer/farther
cameraMovements.push: Push In: Camera or zoom moves closer to subject for emphasis
cameraMovements.pull: Pull Out: Camera or zoom moves away from subject
cameraMovements.tracking: Tracking Shot: Camera follows a moving subject
cameraMovements.handheld: Handheld: Camera held by operator for natural, organic movement
cameraMovements.steadicam: Steadicam: Stabilized camera for smooth movement while walking
cameraMovements.crane: Crane Shot: Camera moves vertically using a crane or jib
cameraMovements.whip: Whip Pan: Very fast pan creating motion blur, often used for transitions
cameraMovements.arc: Arc: Camera moves in a curved path around the subject

transitions.cut: Cut: Instant switch from one shot to another
transitions.jump cut: Jump Cut: Abrupt cut within the same shot, creates jarring effect
transitions.match cut: Match Cut: Cut between two similar shapes or actions
transitions.fade: Fade: Gradual transition to/from black or white
transitions.dissolve: Dissolve: One shot gradually blends into another
transitions.wipe: Wipe: New shot slides in over the previous shot
transitions.swipe: Swipe: Similar to wipe, new shot slides in over the previous shot
transitions.zoom: Zoom Transition: Quick zoom used to transition between shots
transitions.whip: Whip Transition: Very fast pan creating motion blur for transitions
transitions.J-cut: J-Cut: Audio from next scene starts before the visual
transitions.L-cut: L-Cut: Audio from previous scene continues over new visual
transitions.smash cut: Smash Cut: Abrupt cut for dramatic contrast or comedic effect
